Core support to Legal and Human Rights Centre (LHRC)for their Strategic plan 2013-2018, phase 1 (2013-2015). Continued Swedish support, started in 2001. The objectives are to reduce HR violations, enhance women's and men's knowledge of human rights and their ability & conditions to defend their rights, as well as strengthening the capacity of duty-bearers to respect human rights.

description.narrative: 1. Citizen-centered constitution achieved and all laws reviewed to be consistent with the new constitution. The Strategic Plan intended to establish awareness raising programmes on the Constitution and establish a network of monitors to ensure the Constitutional Commission consults and considers people’s view. The Plan also aimed at documenting the Constitutional process and sharing it widely. In 2017, LHRC developed a strategy for engaging with different stakeholders to revive the Constitution-making process - demanding a new citizen centered constitution where human rights are enshrined and that ensures Government accountability to its citizens. LHRC collaborated and networked with like-minded individuals and organisations in order to establish a massive movement that demanded this new constitution, in an evidence based manner, in a context where there was neither political will for it by the Government nor their priority. Youth at universities were targeted to be part of this movement. They were for example provided with constitution literacy training. LHRC also partnered with faith-based organisations, media houses (mainstream media and community radios), and others to spread the message of a need for a new constitution, get people engaged in the dialogue and in the movement. Social media and online platforms were also used. In addition, LHRC collaborated with other major Tanzanian human rights organisations working towards the same goal. LHRC managed to create a vivid movement that demanded the resumption of a new constitution making process. A process with an aim of making the constitution citizen centred, i.e. ensure it enshrines human rights and accountability. Media, CSOs, FBOs, secondary and higher learning students' human rights associations, experts, and decision makers were all part of the movement. Due to political disinterest the achievement of a new constitution, in line with the above was, however, not achieved during the period. I.e. an external risk came into play that LHRC could not do much about. However, LHRC continues to build on this created movement in order to push for continued action towards this goal within the contribution that reflects EoS' new support to LHRC (contribution 12829). The evaluation of LHRC's implementation of its Strategic Plan 2013-2018 specifically highlighted this area as a success. 80% of the respondents interviewed indicated that the activities undertaken by LHRC towards realizing a new Constitution have had an impact. Impact includes the fact that the public was sensitized and gave views on the Constitution; the process was documented and shared widely; public opinion was included in the Constitutional Review Commission; and even some said a network of monitors was established and effectively monitored proper consultation of people. 2. Improved laws, policies and practises that are human rights sensitive. As per the Strategic Plan LHRC also intended to undertake strategic litigation on cases which could advance law reform and/or lead to enactment of new legislation. In addition, LHRC was to undertake periodic critical analysis of the data that came out from their legal aid work and their human rights monitoring work so that such analysis could contribute to LHRC's advocacy efforts. The Parliament, the Judiciary and the Executive were all to be engaged in reforms of policies that ensured mainstreaming of human rights. The evaluation shows that LHRC did engage government departments, the Parliament and civil society to advocate for the various reforms, for example, the Minister responsible for regional administration and local government, Minister of Constitutional and Legal Affairs, Minister of Finance and Planning, Minister of Foreign Affairs and East Africa Cooperation, the Law Reform Commission (LRC), and various parliamentary committees. LHRC filed several strategic cases in courts - both Tanzanian courts and regional court - e.g. challenging the constitutionality of the Statistics Act, the Cyber Crimes Act, the Police Force and Auxiliary Act, but also challenging the mandatory death penalty in the Miscellaneous Civil Case. All cases proceeded on merit without facing preliminary objection. On the online content regulation case, the regional court instituted an injunction of the application of the online content regulation pending determination of the main case. This is positive since it means that the law cannot be used until the case has reached a final conclusion. 60% of all recommendations that LHRC put forward on bills tabled in the Parliament were taken onboard according to the evaluation. This is certainly an example of successful influence on making laws and policies more human rights sensitive. 3. Reduced human rights violations and injustices. The Strategic Plan intended to strengthen LHRC's human rights monitoring and human rights reporting mechanism. The Plan also aimed at increasing the numbers of, and strengthen the capacity of, the paralegals who provide legal assistance in the communities. In addition, the Plan focused to design and to dessiminate rights-based public empowerment materials, research and publications. During the period, LHRC successfully monitored the national human rights situation in Tanzania, gathered data on all human rights violations, analysed such data and published it in their annual human rights reports. These human rights reports are the main human rights situational reports produced in Tanzania. These reports were distributed (approx. 3000 copies per year) in order to highligt and draw attention to the human rights violations and injustices that occur in the country. The launches of these reports are always highly covered by media outlets (approx. 40-50 media outlets).Over the past six years (2013-2019), LHRC attended to a total of 7,047 reported human rights cases of which 5,489 cases (78%) were reported by men and 1,558 cases (22%) were reported by women. In addition to these human rights reports, LHRC produces a range of other different publications which they disseminate to various duty bearers, civil society actors, private sector actors, media outlets, libraries, universities, schools etc. In terms of the provision of legal aid, the evaluation concludes that the effectiveness of LHRC's legal aid clinics is so well-known and appreciated for its effectiveness that even duty bearers such as the police, the judiciary, and labour ministry officials refer clients to LHRC. Moreover, over 90% of the respondents in the evaluation stated that the projects and activities of the LHRC conform to the needs and priorities of the clients, in particular the Legal Aid Clinic clients, paralegals and Human Rights Monitors. Over the past six years (2013-2018), LHRC attended a total of 102,025 clients comprised of men 62,868 (62%) and women 30,157 (38%). 4. Government and corporate compliance with regional and international standards with regards to economic, social and environmental rights increased. As per the Strategic Plan LHRC intended during the period to establish a mechanism that would be able to monitor companies' compliance with regional and international human rights standards (economic, social and environmental rights) as well as ensure their compliance with such. The Plan also aimed at following up and naming companies that violated human rights. The evaluation found that LHRC succeeded in establishing a company compliance system that tracks violations by companies of these rights. LHRC has monitored and reported on companies’ practices that violate human rights and increased the capacity of the Government to uphold and comply with international and regional human rights standards. It reported that LHRC's efforts had contributed to a significant increase in the number of companies that were exposed with regards to their non-compliance to social, economic and environmental standards. LHRC also published annual reports on Business and Human Rights which received great acclaim nationally since there were no such previous reports. Under this goal, LHRC has also pursued cases up to the international arena in order to protect the right of the local people who have been exploited over the years by businesses. E.g. LHRC filed a case in London against a multi-national company accused of perpetrating human rights abuses in Tanzania. 5. A relevant, sustainable and high impact LHRC. As per the Strategic Plan for the period (2013-2018), LHRC's ambition under this goal was to strengthen its performance monitoring, its evaluation system and maintain an effective human resource management system. To achieve this intended aim, the Plan foresaw the strengthening of leadership and governance within the organisation. The Strategic Plan also focused on broadening the financial base of LHRC and establishing efficient and effective communication, ICT and documentation systems. The evaluation found that LHRC had trained its staff members on ICT systems, e.g. the softwares used for its documentation, its human resource management, and its legal aid management systems (LAMS) softwares. LAMS is used for handling LHRC's legal aid clients. Data from some of these systems is, for example, used when generating both their general human rights reports and their human rights and business reports. The evaluation states that these systems have proven to provide useful data for LHRC's advocacy efforts and are used as a barometer in measuring the adherence to human rights standards in the country. Under this goal, LHRC also worked to improve the capacity of its staff and volunteers to help them understand the organizational structure, core values, policies and operational systems of LHRC. Moreover, LHRC started to plan for an enhanced safety and security awareness among LHRC staff, Paralegals and Monitors, which included the development of safety and security risk management policies and manuals /guidelines. The security work will be pursued further in the next agreement the Embassy of Sweden will have with LHRC (2019-2021). During this period LHRC has also successfully managed a shift in the top leadership. The previous Executive Director who had been with the organisation since its start retired. In this process of acquiring a new management team, LHRC initiated a succession process of recruiting the Executive Director but also filling the position of the Director of Finance and Administration within the organisation. A process started whereby five individuals in the organisation were identified. They underwent a mentoring programme, obtaining skills in leadership and managment, and subsequently went through a series of interview sessions with the LHRC Board. A final candidate was selected. This is proof of that fact that LHRC has successfully put its succession into practice whereby a person within the organisation grew from being a volunteer to becoming the Executive Director position.
